Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: A critical service is slowing under load and traces point to their recently merged functions
Story:
It’s Saturday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Call us when you can.” I glance at it, guilt prickling at the back of my mind. I haven’t called home in two weeks, just sent a few quick texts. I know they want to hear my voice, to know I’m okay, to feel like I’m still part of their lives even though I’m far away.

But my laptop screen is filled with error logs and performance graphs. The new code I pushed on Friday is causing our main service to crawl, and the team is counting on me to fix it before Monday. My lead has already messaged twice, asking for updates. I can’t let the team down, not with the project’s deadline looming.

I stare at my phone, then back at the code. My parents’ faces flash in my mind, their voices warm and expectant. At the same time, the pressure of the broken service weighs heavy on my chest. I want to be a good son, but I also need to be a reliable developer. My hands hover over the keyboard, torn between dialing home and diving back into the code, caught in the silent tug-of-war between family and work.
